metadata.title: Facile synthesis of nanoporous CuS nanospheres for high-performance supercapacitor electrodes

In recent years, development of high-performance supercapacitor electrode materials has stimulated a great deal of scientific research. The electrochemical performance of a supercapacitor strongly depends on its material structures. Herein, we report a simple strategy for high-performance supercapacitors by building pseudocapacitive CuS nanospheres with nanoporous structures, nanosized walls (<10nm) and relatively large specific surface area of 65m2/g. This electrode demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance including a maximum specific capacitance of 814F/g at 1A/g, significant rate capability of 42% capacitance retention at an ultrafast rate of 50A/g, and outstanding long-term cycling stability at various current densities. The remarkable electrochemical performance of as-prepared nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrode has been attributed to its unique structures that plays a key role in providing short ion and electron diffusion pathways, facilitated ion transport and more active sites for electrochemical reactions. This work sheds a new light on the metal sulfides design philosophy, and demonstrates that nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrode is a promising candidate for application in high-performance supercapacitors. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract We developed a facile rout to synthesize nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrodes with unique properties. These electrodes demonstrate an ultra-high specific capacitance (814F/g at 1A/g), excellent rate capability and cycle life. Keywords Supercapacitor Nanoporous CuS Nanospheres 1 Introduction During the past half century, because of rapid depletion of fossil fuels and increasing environmental pollution, clean and renewable energy sources (i.e., fuel cells, lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors) have been developed intensely [1,2]. Among these sources, supercapacitors (SCs), which offer higher power density, much longer cycle life, lower maintenance cost and safer operation than others, have attracted considerable attention [3]. Based on the charge storage mechanism, SCs classified into two types: electrical double layer capacitors (EDLC) and pseudocapacitors. Pseudocapacitors such as metal oxides/hydroxides offer much higher specific capacitance and energy density than EDLCs (carbonaceous materials) [4–6]. Very recently, various transition metal sulfides such as CoS [7], NiS [8], ZnS [9], SnS [10], CuS [11–13], CuCo2S4 [14], CoNi2S4 [15] and NiCo2S4 [16] are receiving increasing attention as pseudocapacitive electrode materials due to high electrochemical performance, rich valences, more complex valence states compared to oxides, and good chemical stability [17]. Among these transition metal sulfides, CuS is a promising candidate due to its low cost, elemental abundance, various shapes at the nanoscale and metal-like electronic conductivity (10−3 S/cm) [11,18]. Raj et al. [11] reported CuS nanoplates on FTO substrates with a maximum specific capacitance of 73F/g. Zhu et al. [19] synthesized CuS nanoneedles on a CNT backbone with a maximum specific capacitance of 122F/g. Huang et al. [20] prepared the different morphologies of CuS nanosheets assisted by SDBS and CTAB surfactants with a specific capacitance of 232 and 379F/g, respectively. Hsu et al. [21] grew CuS nanowire arrays on Cu foil with a maximum specific capacitance of 305F/g. Peng et al. [22] reported hierarchical structures of CuS that demonstrated a maximum specific capacitance of 597F/g. Peng et al. [18] synthesized multi-structural CuS@polypyrrole composites with a specific capacitance of 427F/g. It has been accepted that the performance of supercapacitor electrode materials strongly depends on their morphologies and nanostructure properties [4]. The morphology and nanostructures of materials determine their specific surface area, pore-size distribution and wall thickness [23–25]. These features are the key factors that define the active sites for electrochemical reactions, accessibility of electrolyte, transport/diffusion paths and kinetics of the supercapacitor electrodes [24,26]. Hence, developing electrodes with improved features is very desirable. In this view, nanoporous structures with high surface area, narrow pore size and nanoscale particle size are the promising candidates [27,28]. Herein, we develop a facile synthesis route to prepare nanoporous CuS nanospheres with high surface area and narrow pore size distribution for high-performance supercapacitor electrode material, for the first time. This nanoporous CuS electrode exhibits ultrahigh specific capacitance (814F/g at 1A/g) with excellent rate capability and cycle life that demonstrates its potential as a high performance electrode material for supercapacitor application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of nanoporous CuS nanospheres All the reagents were of analytical purity and used as received without further purification. In a typical synthesis, 1.25g of the triblock copolymer Pluronic P123 (average M W = 5800, EO20PO70EO20, Aldrich) was dissolved in 60mL distilled water. 0.341g of CuCl2·2H2O (Aldrich) was dissolved in 10mL distilled water, followed by addition of the appropriate volume of ammonia solution (NH3·H2O, 25%, Merck) in order to preparation of Cu(NH3)4 2+. The molar ratio of NH3 to Cu2+ was kept at 10:1. Then, 4.5mL of above Cu(NH3)4 2+ solution was poured into the solution of P123 and stirred at room temperature for 30min. After addition of ascorbic acid (10mL, 0.6M, Merck), the solution was kept under stirring for another 15min. The result mixture was heated to 160°C and a given amount of thiourea (with a thiourea:copper molar ratio of 2:1) was quickly injected and the mixture was transferred into a stainless-steel autoclaves and maintained at 160°C for 24h. Finally, the resulting black precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and distilled water several times to remove the P123. For the synthesis of bulk CuS, the above procedure was repeated without the Pluronic P123. 2.2 Characterization Structurally characterization of the prepared samples were performed using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Philips X'pert diffractometer with Cu Kα radi-ation (λ= 0.154nm) generated at 40kV and 30mA with a step size of 0.04°/s). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption, specific surface area and pore size distributions were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP-2010 apparatus at 77K. The morphologies and structural investigations of the samples were done by a Zeiss field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and a Philips EM 208 transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDAX). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements For electrochemical measurements, the electrodes were prepared by mixing active material, acetylene black, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, as a binder) with a mass ratio of 85:10:5. A 10% solution of the mixture in acetone was prepared and coated on nickel foam as the current collector by a coater (S.C.S.90 model, Modern Technology Development Institute, Iran). The specific mass loading of the active material for each electrode was about 2.5mg/cm2. The prepared electrodes were used as the working electrodes; and all electrochemical investigations were performed using a three electrode system with Hg/HgO electrodes and platinum plates as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All potentials were referred to the reference electrode and all electrochemical measurements were performed at room temperature in aqueous 6M KOH solution on a BioLogic VSP 300 potentiostat/galvanostat device. The specific capacitances (C sp), energy densities (ED, Wh/kg) and power densities (PD, W/kg) were calculated from the discharge curves using the following equations: (1) C sp = I Δ t m Δ V (2) ED = C sp Δ V 2 2 (3) PD = ED Δ t where I is the discharge current (A), ∆t is the discharge time (s), ∆V is the potential window (V), and m is the mass loading (g). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization The crystallinity and phase purity of the as prepared nanospheres and bulk CuS samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis as shown in Fig 1 (a). All diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns of the both samples are well matched with the standard pattern of hexagonal phase CuS (covellite type, JCPDS card No: 06-0464, a = 3.792Å, b = 3.792Å and c = 16.344Å) with no characteristic peaks assigned to possible impurities such as Cu2S, Cu2O or CuO. The sharp and intense peaks in the XRD patterns of both samples indicate their good crystallinity. Furthermore, the broader diffraction peaks of the nanosphere sample suggest the formation of smaller size crystallites. The purity and CuS composition of the nanospheres were further confirmed by EDAX analysis. As can be seen in Fig 1(b), only strong peaks for Cu and S are found in the spectrum. The atomic ratio of copper to sulfur, calculated from the quantification of the peaks, is 50.6:49.4 which is in agreement with the 1:1 stoichiometric ratio of CuS. The corresponding nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the as-prepared samples are shown in Fig 1(c). As can be seen, nanosphere sample exhibits a typical IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop that is characteristic for mesoporous/nanoporous materials [29], while bulk sample has a type II isotherm that is characteristic for non-porous/macroporous materials. The BET specific surface area of the nanoporous CuS nanospheres is calculated to be 65m2/g, which is much higher than that of bulk CuS (7m2/g). The BJH analysis of nanospheres (inset of Fig. 1c) reveals their narrow pore size distribution centered at 7nm. The morphology and interior structure of the as-prepared samples were investigated by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 1(d) and (e) shows the typical FESEM and TEM images of the nanoporous CuS sample. As can be seen, all spheres have a uniform size and shape with nanoporous structure, and without any by-products such as bulks or non-spherical shapes. The size of the spheres typically ranges from 90 to 110nm, and their average nanopore size and wall thickness are estimated to be less than 10nm. Fig. 1(f) shows the FESEM image of bulk CuS sample. Irregular shapes with various particle sizes without nanopores can be observed from this image. The high specific surface area, nanocrystalline thin walls and well-developed nanoporous structures are the key factors in energy storage systems providing more active sites for electrochemical reactions, shorter diffusion paths and rapid electrolyte transport [24,30–32]. Therefore, it can be predicted that nanoporous CuS nanospheres might show much better electrochemical behavior than bulk sample, and can be a promising candidate as a high-performance supercapacitor electrode material. 3.2 Electrochemical evaluation Electrochemical properties of the as-prepared nanospheres and bulk CuS were investigated in a three-electrode cell containing a 6M KOH aqueous solution as the electrolyte. Typical cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the bare electrode (Ni foam), nanospheres and bulk CuS electrodes at a scan rate of 5mV/s are shown in Fig. 2 (a). From the negligible CV integrated area of the Ni foam as compared with those of the other two CuS electrodes, can be clearly found that the current collector has no capacitance contribution. Also, significant enhancement in the specific capacitance of the CuS nanospheres electrode is obviously visible when comparing its CV integrated area with that of the bulk electrode. Furthermore, strong redox peaks observed in the CV curves of the both CuS electrodes reveal the pseudocapacitive characteristics of these electrodes different from the nearly rectangular CV shapes for EDLCs [20,33]. Fig. 2(b) represents typical CV curves of the CuS nanospheres electrode measured at various scan rates ranging from 10 to 100mV/s. As shown, by increasing the scan rate from 10 to 100mV/s, the shape of the CV curves is not significantly influenced, demonstrating its improved mass transport, high rate capability and reversibility of the electrode [24,34]. In order to evaluate the specific capacitances, rate capability and cyclic life of the electrodes, galvanostatic charge/discharge (CD) measurements were performed. The CD curves of the CuS nanospheres electrode in the voltage range of −0.2 to 0.4V at various current densities of 1 to 50A/g are illustrated in Fig. 2(c) and (d). The nonlinear behavior of the CD curves confirms the result from the CV measurements that the charge storage in the CuS nanospheres electrode mainly originates from pseudo capacitance mechanism. Furthermore, low iR drop even at a high current density of 20A/g (as can be seen in Fig. 2d) indicates the high conductivity and low internal resistance of this electrode [35]. From the discharge tests, the ultrahigh specific capacitance of 814F/g was calculated for CuS nanospheres electrode, which is much higher than that of bulk CuS (173F/g) and most of the previously reported CuS materials [11,18–22]. In order to comparison and presentation of the rate capability of the both electrodes, their specific capacitances were illustrated in Fig. 2(e). The specific capacitances of CuS nanospheres electrode are 814, 746, 640, 557, 473, and 339F/g at current densities of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 50A/g, respectively; also, the specific capacitances of bulk CuS electrode are 123, 137, 99, 71, 50 and 30F/g at current densities of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50A/g, respectively. As seen, in all current densities the specific capacitances of CuS nanospheres electrode are higher than those of bulk sample. Although with increasing current densities the specific capacitances of the electrodes decreases, due to insufficient involvement of active material in redox reaction [36,37], however the CuS nanospheres electrode still shows a high capacitance of 339F/g (about 42% retention) even at a high current density of 50A/g. This indicates an excellent rate capability for the CuS nanospheres electrode. Energy density and power density are very important parameters of supercapacitors for the evaluation of their operational performance/efficiency [27]. The Ragone plot, presenting energy density vs. power density, of the CuS electrodes was shown in Fig. 2(f) in order to represent and compare their overall performance. As seen, the CuS nanospheres electrode has a much higher energy densities than bulk electrode. In detail, a maximum energy density of 40.7Wh/kg was achieved for the CuS nanospheres electrode at a power density of 0.3kW/kg, which is much higher than that of bulk sample (8.65Wh/kg). The long-term cycling stability was tested using sequential CD measurements, to further indicate the advantages of the CuS nanospheres electrode architecture on its electrochemical behavior. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the cycling stability of the CuS nanospheres electrode in the first 2000 cycles, with 9.5% capacitance loss at a current density of 2A/g, is much higher than that of bulk electrode (56% capacitance loss) and most of the previously reported CuS electrode materials [18,20,22,33,38,39]. After 2000 cycles at 2A/g, the cycling stability of the CuS nanospheres electrode was further investigated over 3000 cycles at various current densities of 5, 10 and 2A/g. As can be seen, in the next 1000 cycles (at 5A/g) the electrode retained about 91.6% of its capacitance specific capacitance, and at the end of the next 1000 cycles (at 10A/g), the capacitance decreased to 90.9% of its initial value. After 4000 continuous cycles at different current densities, when the current density was turned back to 2A/g, the electrode recovered 96% of its primary capacitance, and finally 95.9% of the capacitance maintained after another 1000 cycles at 2A/g. These results demonstrate remarkable long-term cycling stability of the CuS nanospheres electrode. Further characterization of the electrochemical behavior of the electrodes was performed using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at open circuit potential. Nyquist plots of the CuS nanospheres (before and after cycling) and bulk electrodes are shown in Fig. 3(b). Both electrodes reveal a semicircle at high frequencies, attributed to the charge transfer resistance (R ct) [40,41], followed by a linear slope at the medium or low frequency region corresponded to the Warburg impedance (Z w) [42,43]. The steeper line at low frequencies (for CuS nanospheres electrode) demonstrates the capacitive nature of the electrode (vertical line for an ideal capacitor) [44]. Accordingly, when compared to that of the bulk electrode, the CuS nanospheres electrode has a smaller charge transfer resistance (R ct) and lower equivalent series resistance (ESR, the intercept of the Nyquist curve on the real axis, inset of Fig. 3b), indicating its larger electro-active surface area and higher electrical conductivity [45,46]. Furthermore, a more vertical line of the CuS nanospheres electrode in the low frequency region, suggesting that the nanoporous structure of the CuS nanospheres electrode facilitates the mass transfer of the electrolyte [26,47]. In addition, nearly identical Nyquist plots of the CuS nanospheres electrode before and after cycling further confirm its excellent cycling stability. All of these results demonstrate the excellent pseudocapacitance characteristic features of the CuS nanospheres as a high-performance supercapacitor electrode material. A comparison of the electrochemical performance of nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrode with previously reported CuS electrodes is presented in Table 1 . The outstanding electrochemical performance of the CuS nanospheres electrode with ultrahigh specific capacitance and remarkable long-term cycling stability can be attributed to the following multiple factors: as shown in Scheme 1 , the nanosphere morphology with nanoporous structures enhances the accessibility of electrolyte not only at its surface but also throughout the entire material by acting as ion-buffering reservoirs thus minimizes the diffusion distance from the external electrolyte to the interior surfaces [8,31]; the high specific surface area (65m2/g) provides more active sites with larger interfacial area between the electrode material and the electrolyte ions for the electrochemical reactions thus improves the utilization of the active material [48,49]; the thin wall thickness (less than 10nm) provides short diffusion/transport pathways for ions/electrons thus leads to faster kinetics and higher conductivity [50,51]. 4 Conclusions We have developed CuS nanospheres electrodes with nanoporous structure, high specific surface area, and nanosized walls. The CuS nanospheres electrode exhibits high specific capacitance of 814F/g at 1A/g, remarkable rate capability, high energy density and outstanding cycling stability at different current densities, due to its unique structural features that minimize the diffusion distance, improve the utilization of the active material and provide faster kinetics and higher conductivity. The nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrodes with these unique structural properties and distinguished electrochemical performance are a promising candidate for application in high-performance supercapacitors. This work also gives some insights into the design of metal sulfide electrodes used in a various range of applications such as catalysis, gas sensors, lithium ion batteries, biosensors, and other electronic devices. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, development of high-performance supercapacitor electrode materials has stimulated a great deal of scientific research. The electrochemical performance of a supercapacitor strongly depends on its material structures. Herein, we report a simple strategy for high-performance supercapacitors by building pseudocapacitive CuS nanospheres with nanoporous structures, nanosized walls (<10nm) and relatively large specific surface area of 65m2/g. This electrode demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance including a maximum specific capacitance of 814F/g at 1A/g, significant rate capability of 42% capacitance retention at an ultrafast rate of 50A/g, and outstanding long-term cycling stability at various current densities. The remarkable electrochemical performance of as-prepared nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrode has been attributed to its unique structures that plays a key role in providing short ion and electron diffusion pathways, facilitated ion transport and more active sites for electrochemical reactions. This work sheds a new light on the metal sulfides design philosophy, and demonstrates that nanoporous CuS nanospheres electrode is a promising candidate for application in high-performance supercapacitors.

coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of nanoporous CuS nanospheres for high-performance supercapacitor electrodes
